content.webTitle: Why having the right health fund can make all the difference when it matters

fields.headline: Why having the right health fund can make all the difference when it matters
fields.bodyText: Life doesn’t always go to plan. In an unexpected health crisis, we want the option of fast access to the top doctors, the right hospital care and everything we need to recover. Meet three people who are thankful they chose not-for-profit funds, which gave them the best cover when they really needed it. Coverage for the most unexpected discoveries Sergeant Topher McLoughlin had been serving in the police force for almost three decades when an event on duty changed the course of his life. “I got bitten for the umpteenth time by a client and subsequently got a blood test,” he says. What might have been a routine check took a devastating turn. “I sat across from my GP who started to cry. He told me that I had stage-four lymphoma.” In Mt Isa, where McLoughlin was based, the hospital didn’t have the facilities to treat his cancer. He had no choice but to urgently fly 2,000km to Brisbane. “I got into Brisbane and did all the checks, and then came back home and had to tell my wife the prognosis: horrendous,” McLoughlin says. The change was difficult for the whole family, but McLoughlin’s Police Health cover meant he could access the best treatment. “All of a sudden you’ve gone from having to fight outlaw motorcycle gangs - which is my speciality - to how do you fight your own body? I struggled with that mentally. And then the reality set in that I would have to fly every three weeks. I could really see it was going to be quite expensive.” In an unexpected health crisis, we want the option of fast access to the top doctors, the right hospital care and everything we need to recover. Photograph: Ariel Skelley/Getty Images. For months, McLoughlin lived in Leukemia House, a facility in Brisbane that services patients flying in from western Queensland. “When I first started, I would look at our bank account every day and think, how much is this costing? My wife kept saying, honey, you don’t have to worry about it. You’ve got full cover. Whatever is not available at Mt Isa, we can fly into Brisbane and get it there.” That was three years ago. Of all the men McLoughlin befriended in Leukemia House, none are left. “Most of those guys didn’t have health cover,” he says. “They were selling their houses, selling their assets. When they died, their family had nothing at all.” Now, McLoughlin tells everyone living out west that they can’t afford to be without private health insurance. “The further remote you are, the longer you have to wait.” In regional and rural areas, there might only be one doctor, one hospital. He says having more choices has been worth every dollar he’s paid. “For the people who think it’s too expensive, it isn’t. No one says no. It’s that wonderful, safe feeling that someone’s got you covered, and you can lower your guard and say, I really need help.” Real support for the whole family Mel Tinkler’s son, Max, plays VFL football. She says watching him is a battle with her nerves: “I sit and watch football with my heart in my mouth.” To protect him - and the rest of the family - she looked to her industry’s restricted fund, Teachers Health. “I’d heard by word of mouth that it was a good fund, and when I read up and had a look at the literature, I liked that it was for teachers,” she says. “There were a lot of benefits that were specific to teaching. I needed physio, and the physio rebate was a lot higher than the others. I liked that it was not-for-profit and the money was put back into offering a wider variety of services: it has things like optometry, dentistry and massage therapy. You don’t realise, until you get onto the website and navigate around, how many things you can do.” “We were able to get Australia’s best doctor for knee surgery ... he was able to operate within a week” - Max was back on the field in no time. Photograph: Cameron Spencer/Getty Images. But the peace of mind for her children was even more important. “I wanted to be covered so we could get the very best practitioners and in the quickest time possible, choosing a hospital that we could access quickly.” When Max, 23, had a footy injury requiring two knee reconstructions, the family’s private health insurance came into its own. “We were able to get Australia’s best doctor for knee surgery,” Mel says. “He was able to operate within a week.” Max was back on the field in no time. Mel’s kids may be adults, but they’re still protected by her Teachers Health cover. “You’re still a parent. It’s always the kids; you put yourself second. With the kids, you want the very best for them.” Knowing you’re covered when there’s no time to waste Dianne, 72, was having an MRI to investigate Parkinson’s disease when doctors discovered she had a brain tumour. “It was 8cm long,” she says. Life-saving surgery needed to happen right away. “I didn’t have time to think about it. I was straight into hospital, transferred to Sydney at midnight. There was no time for discussions or questions. I met my neurosurgeon on the way into the operating theatre.” A month after her surgery, Dianne wondered why she wasn’t receiving any bills. “I thought something had gone wrong in the system. I rang my surgeon’s rooms and asked when they were going to start sending me bills, and they said, no, you won’t be getting any bills.” Dianne’s not-for-profit health fund, HCF, covered every part of her care. “There was no gap at all.” You never know when you might need to be covered. Make sure you’re protected and have the right cover when you need it. Photograph: Morsa Images / Getty images. Now, Dianne runs an online support website for people who have the same type of brain tumours as she had. After using it to get more information about her own diagnosis, she got on board to help others. Part of Dianne’s work is helping people make sure they have the right cover, something she says is really important to her. “I’m constantly typing, ‘check with your fund’. Ask them: what does this cover me for, what hospitals are you affiliated with, is there a waiting period to be covered?” These same questions have saved Dianne years of stress and uncertainty. “I could have been impacted by a bill of multiple thousands of dollars, and I wasn’t,” she says. “It was a great relief.” These are just three examples from the community of Members Health funds, of which there are 27 to choose from – each putting people’s health before profits. Some are linked to key industries – doctors, nurses and midwives, military and navy personnel, teachers, police and emergency services, or financial services – while others are open to everyone. You never know when you might need to be covered. Make sure you’re protected and have the right cover when you need it. Choosing the right health fund can literally save your life. To learn more about Members Health and the funds that put people before profits, go to membershealth.com.au.
